column2: Trump revisits talk of 'rigged election'	"

column1: By Steve Holland
| PORTSMOUTH
column2: N.H.

column1: PORTSMOUTH
column2: N.H. U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump
column3: fighting to overcome setbacks and polls showing a tough path to the White House
column4: on Saturday doubled down on his claim that the U.S. election is rigged against him.Trump challenged accusations from several women that he made unwanted sexual advances toward them. Trump spokesman Jason Miller denied a new allegation that surfaced on Saturday
column5: saying there was ""no way"" Trump had kissed a woman without permission 20 years ago at his Florida resort.Trump told an outdoor rally in New Hampshire on Saturday that the media was sharing the accusations against him to boost Democrat Hillary Clinton and damage his own White House hopes.Trump has presented no evidence for claims he has made for months that the election could be fixed to prevent him from reaching the Oval Office. Leaders on both sides of the political spectrum worry that this rhetoric
column6: which supporters sometimes repeat in interviews
column7: undermines the democratic process.""It looks to me like a rigged election
column8: Trump said in New Hampshire. ""The election is being rigged by corrupt media pushing completely false allegations and outright lies in an effort to elect her president.""He started the day tweeting several times that the election was being swayed by a media conspiracy. ""This election is being rigged by the media pushing false and unsubstantiated charges
column10: in order to elect Crooked Hillary!"" he said in one Twitter post. He reiterated similar claims at a later rally in Bangor

column1: Clinton
column2: a former U.S. secretary of state
column3: led Trump by seven percentage points in the most recent Reuters/Ipsos national opinion poll of voters. A new analysis found she was heavily favored to reach the 270 Electoral College votes needed to secure the presidency.Trump's campaign said on Saturday it had raised a total of $100 million in September
column4: mostly from small donors but also including a $2 million monthly contribution from Trump. At the same time
column5: the campaign squabbled with the Republican party in Ohio
column6: a key swing state in the Nov. 8 election
column7: whose Republican leaders have not been shy about concerns with Trump. On Saturday
column8: Trump's Ohio state director released a letter saying that Ohio Republican Party Chairman Matt Borges ""no longer has any affiliation"" with the campaign. Borges responded that the state party had been actively helping Trump there.

column1: Trump's speech in New Hampshire was intended to focus on a plan to end deaths caused by opioid overdoses
column2: something he often mentions on the campaign trail. But he deviated from policy proposals to air his allegations of election-rigging and his response to new groping accusations
column3: 24 days before the election.Trump has been fending off the accusations since the release of a 2005 video in which he was recorded bragging about making unwanted sexual advances toward women. Trump has said the boasts were merely words and he has denied each of the allegations.The latest woman to come forward
column4: Cathy Heller
column6: of New York
column7: told the Guardian newspaper that in or around 1997
column8: Trump kissed her on the lips upon first meeting her during a Mother's Day brunch at his Florida estate. She told the newspaper she leaned away
column10: and he kissed the side of her mouth.Reuters could not confirm the allegations by Heller
column11: who has contributed to Clinton's campaign. The Guardian said it spoke to a relative who saw part of the interaction.

column1: There is no way that something like this would have happened in a public place on Mother's Day at Mr. Trump's resort
column2: Miller
column3: the Trump spokesman
column4: said in a statement. ""It would have been the talk of Palm Beach for the past two decades.""On Saturday
column5: Trump deemed ""crazy"" another woman
column6: Jessica Leeds
column8: who said he groped her on an airplane in or around 1980. He also denied allegations of unwanted contact by Summer Zervos
column9: a former contestant on Trump's show ""The Apprentice
column10: who said he kissed her during a meeting about a possible job. Trump said Zervos' first cousin called her a ""huge fan of Donald Trump
column11: referring to a letter the campaign released to media.Trump also told the New Hampshire crowd that he and Clinton were ""like athletes"" gearing up for the final presidential debate on Wednesday in Las Vegas
column12: and he implied Clinton might have been on drugs during their last match-up.""I think we should take a drug test prior to the debate
column13: Trump said. ""In the beginning of her last debate she was all pumped up at the beginning and at the end she was like uh
column14: take me down."" (Reporting by Steve Holland; Writing by Emily Stephenson; Editing by Mary Milliken and Leslie Adler)"

U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump pledged that the United States and India would be ""best friends"" if he is elected and that he would boost intelligence sharing with India in the battle against Islamic militants.Trump spoke at an event sponsored by the Republican Hindu Coalition to raise money for victims of terrorism. It featured Bollywood-style performers who danced in colorful

column5: that I can guarantee you

3	http://reuters.com/article/us-golf-lpga-whan-idUSKBN12F0BB	LPGA happy to let USGA make Trump course decision	"
By Peter Rutherford
| INCHEON
column2: South Korea

column1: INCHEON
column2: South Korea LPGA chief Mike Whan says the Tour will back golf authorities no matter what decision they make about hosting the 2017 US Women's Open at a course owned by presidential nominee Donald Trump amid a storm over sexually aggressive comments he made about women.The United States Golf Association (USGA) is facing calls to move the event from Trump National Golf Club in New Jersey in nine months' time after a 2005 video surfaced in which he bragged of kissing and groping women without consent.Whan told Reuters in an interview on Saturday at the LPGA/KLPGA co-sanctioned KEB Hana Bank Championship in Incheon that he was ""lucky"" not to have to make that kind of decision.The U.S. Women's Open
column3: the most prestigious tournament in ladies golf
column4: is conducted by the USGA. ""In a strange way I'm lucky that the LPGA has no direct dealings with Donald Trump or Donald Trump properties
column5: he said.""Like any group we have people who are political in favor of different sides. I'm not here to be a politician
column6: I know that what the players want is that I don't get so political as to limit opportunities for women.""All I've said to the USGA is this
column7: 'You have long since proven you support women's golf so if you tell us this is the right place to play then we're right there with you.'""

column1: Whan took over in 2010 when the LPGA Tour was buckling from the fallout of the U.S. recession and his push for global growth has been a key factor in the circuit's resurgence.One look at his business card tells you everything you need to know about his strategy for growing the women's game -- the word ""commissioner"" emblazoned in English
column2: Korean
column3: Chinese and Japanese.Whan said he hoped the global flavor of the Tour's  schedule and sponsorship could help mitigate the effects of another downturn at home.

column1: In the world of finance we have a pretty diverse portfolio
column2: he said of a tour which makes stops in China
column3: Japan
column4: Malaysia
column5: Korea and Taiwan in a late season Asian swing.More than a third of the circuit's tournaments are sponsored by Asian firms or organizations.""It used to be that one U.S. economic downturn could really cripple the LPGA
column6: he added. ""I'm not saying that wouldn't happen tomorrow
column7: but generally speaking we are pretty well diversified regionally.""Whan said now that the Tour had been put on a solid footing
column8: with 33 official money events this year compared to 23 in 2011
column9: the task was to boost the dollar value of tournaments rather than add new ones.

column1: I think we need to be playing for $100 million in purse money
column2: he said of future targets. ""I said that back in 2010 and people thought I was nuts
column3: but that was when we were playing for $30 million.""Now we're play for $65 million and I think we'll get there.""The decision to add a fifth major to the annual tour schedule
column4: the Evian Championship
column5: was met with scorn by traditionalists and those outside the LPGA but Whan said it would be a mistake to be stuck in the past.""Sports that are unwilling to change because of history and tradition become historic and traditional
column6: he added. ""If we just want golf to be historic and traditional and not move forward
column7: then we would have a real problem."" (Editing by Amlan Chakraborty)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKBN12F0PC	Clinton heavily favored to win Electoral College: poll	"
By Maurice Tamman
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK After a brutal week for Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump
column2: Democrat Hillary Clinton maintained a substantial projected advantage in the race to win the Electoral College and claim the U.S. presidency
column3: according to the latest results from the Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project released on Saturday.If the election were held this week
column4: the project estimates that Clinton's odds of securing the 270 Electoral College votes needed to win the presidency at more than 95 percent
column5: and by a margin of 118 Electoral College votes. It is the second week in a row that the project has estimated her odds so high.__________________________STATES OF THE NATIONCheck out the state-by-state breakdown and run your own scenarios based on voter turnout___________________________

column1: The results mirror other Electoral College projections
column2: some of which estimate Clinton's chance of winning at around 90 percent.

column1: For the Trump campaign there are a handful of states the Republican candidate must win if he is to cobble together enough states to win the White House.Among them is Florida
column2: but numerous recent visits to the Sunshine State by Trump and his vice-presidential running mate Mike Pence did little to dent Clinton's advantage in the contest for the state's 29 Electoral College votes. She leads by 6 percentage points
column3: about the same lead she enjoyed last week.Still
column4: the race tightened in Ohio
column5: another important state for Trump. Both Ohio and Nevada were leaning toward Clinton last week but are now toss-ups.

column1: However
column2: Clinton's support grew in North Carolina and Colorado
column3: both of which moved from toss-ups to leaning Clinton.In the last week
column4: the Trump campaign struggled to respond to allegations from several women that Trump had groped them or made unwanted sexual advances over several decades. Trump said the reports were lies and part of a media conspiracy to defeat him.All of the allegations came after The Washington Post disclosed a video from 2005 of Trump describing how he tried to seduce a married woman and bragged in vulgar terms how his celebrity allowed him to kiss and grope women without permission.The accusations overshadowed what might otherwise have been a difficult week for Clinton. Her campaign manager's email account was apparently hacked and thousands of his emails were released by Wikileaks. U.S. officials say the Russian government sanctioned the electronic break-in.

column1: The emails have been trickling out for two weeks. Included in the hacked emails were undisputed comments that Clinton made to banks and big business in a 2014 speech. In those comments
column2: Clinton said she supports open trade and open borders
column3: and takes a conciliatory approach to Wall Street
column4: both positions she later backed away from.Since that release
column5: waves of other emails have been released
column6: among which were some that suggested Clinton had inappropriately received questions in advance of a debate with Bernie Sanders during the Democratic primaries.Without Trump's own woes
column7: the Clinton emails may well have become the central issue in the campaign. Yet with just over three weeks to go until the Nov. 8 election
column8: Trump does not have much time to turn the race around.According to the project
column9: Trump trails by double-digits among women and all minority groups. Among black voters he trails by nearly 70 points. To a large extent his support is almost entirely dependent on white voters. And while Trump's support among white men is strong
column10: among white women his lead is negligible. (Reporting by Maurice Tamman; Editing by Reg Chua and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-rallies-idUSKBN12F0AX	How Trump rallies the faithful: Belittle Clinton
column2: news media	"

column1: By Steve Holland
| CHARLOTTE
column2: N.C.

column1: CHARLOTTE
column2: N.C. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's campaign rallies have turned into eruptions of barely contained emotions from his impassioned followers
column3: who urge him to fight on despite a series of gut punches that have put his chances of winning in doubt.With the Nov. 8 election now only weeks away and polls turning against him
column4: Trump is spending precious time in campaign speeches defending himself from accusations from several women who say he made unwanted sexual advances toward them.What he would do if elected is covered
column5: but much of his speeches are spent belittling his Democratic opponent
column6: Hillary Clinton. He also accuses the U.S. news media of a plot to bring him down
column7: and charges that the women who have made the accusations against him might be doing it for a taste of fame.Opinion polls show a gloomy picture for Trump. A week after a video surfaced of him bragging in lewd terms about groping women
column8: the latest Reuters-Ipsos poll on Friday showed Clinton up
column9: with 44 percent to Trump's 37 percent.And the crowds have gotten more protective of their hero. One woman at a rally in Cincinnati
column11: on Thursday wore a homemade T-shirt that said ""Trump Can Grab My
column12: with an arrow pointing to her crotch.On Friday in Greensboro
column14: a man wearing a ""Gays for Trump"" shirt punched a protester who held up an upside down American flag. Both were ejected.Trump's message has gotten through to his supporters in a big way about Clinton
column15: who Trump calls a criminal for her handling of classified information as secretary of state. ""She would be the most dishonest and corrupt ever elected to high office

column1: A crowd of young voters had a ready response when he brought up Clinton at an event in Columbus
column2: Ohio
column3: on Thursday.""Lock her up!"" they chanted
column4: mimicking the lines voiced by older voters at other events.Trump could only smile and shake his head. ""So young and so jaded already
column5: he said.The New York businessman feeds off the energy generated by crowds that pack his rallies by the thousands. But he is easily distracted
column6: lurching from topic to topic based on whatever happens to sprint to mind.

column1: On Wednesday in Lakeland
column2: Florida
column3: Trump jumped from bashing the news media as ""the most dishonest people you'll ever see
column4: to tout his performance at a debate in St. Louis on Sunday - ""which I won big league"" - to Clinton's stroll across the stage in front of him at that event.""And the papers said I invaded her space
column5: he said. ""Believe me
column6: the last space I want to invade is hers.""There are moments of levity. A woman who recovered from a brief fainting spell in the heat of Lakeland was pointed out by Trump.""That woman was out cold and now she is recovered -- a little ding to the head

column1: Trump can form an attack line against Clinton out of pretty much anything that springs to mind.Venting about Chinese trade practices before a raucous crowd of perhaps 20
column2: 000 in Cincinnati on Thursday night
column3: Trump  suddenly imagined how China might treat Clinton given her bout of pneumonia a month ago
column4: which had caused her to nearly collapse at an event in New York.""If she goes down in Tiananmen Square
column5: they'll just leave her
column6: he said. ""They're tough people.""Trump's crowds sometimes get agitated.Many of his supporters are upset at the news media
column7: whipped into a frenzy by both Trump and former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani
column8: who in Cincinnati introduced Trump by condemning ""the insanity of the media
column9: the insanity of the way they cover him.""Upon entering the arena
column10: Trump's traveling press corps was booed by thousands of people who chanted ""tell the truth."" Trump boosters near the media work area repeatedly cursed and taunted reporters.""When are you all going to be ashamed of yourselves?"" one man shouted. ""Lower than Congress -- that's what your approval rating is."" (Reporting by Steve Holland; Editing by Will Dunham)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-obama-idUSKBN12F00N	Obama meets with national security team on Syria
column2: Islamic State	"

column1: WASHINGTON President Barack Obama met on Friday with his national security team to discuss the fight against Islamic State and the war in Syria
column2: the White House said.Reuters had reported that in the meeting Obama and his advisers would consider military and other options in Syria as Syrian and Russian aircraft continue to pummel the city of Aleppo and other targets
column3: U.S. officials said.U.S. officials said they considered it unlikely that Obama would order U.S. air strikes on Syrian government targets
column4: and they stressed that he might not make any decisions at the National Security Council meeting.A readout of the meeting released by the White House noted that the United States had broken off bilateral talks with Russia on reaching a ceasefire in Syria. It said Obama directed his team to continue multilateral talks with ""key nations"" to seek a diplomatic resolution to the civil war.

column1: The brief summary made no mention of other U.S. options in Syria.U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry and Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov will return to Syria talks on Saturday
column2: three weeks after the failure of their painstakingly drafted ceasefire.

column1: Kerry has pointedly avoided new bilateral negotiations with Lavrov
column2: and his invitation to the Turkish
column3: Saudi
column4: Qatari and Iranian foreign ministers to join them for talks in Lausanne
column5: Switzerland
column6: will broaden the discussion to include the most powerful backers of Syria's government and rebels.

column1: Pressure is rising for a halt to a ferocious
column2: three-week-old Syrian government offensive to capture the rebel-held eastern zone of Aleppo
column3: where the United Nations says 275
column4: 000 civilians still live and 8
column5: 000 rebels are holding out against Syrian
column6: Russian and Iranian-backed forces. (Reporting by Eric Beech; Editing by Sandra Maler)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-north-carolina-registrat-idUSKBN12E24E	North Carolina Democrats win extension of voter registration deadline	"
By Colleen Jenkins
| WINSTON-SALEM
column2: N.C.

column1: WINSTON-SALEM
column2: N.C. A state judge in North Carolina gave residents in counties hit hard by Hurricane Matthew five extra days to register to vote after Democrats sued to get an extension to Friday's deadline
column3: while a federal judge ordered an extension in one Georgia county.The Democratic Party in North Carolina challenged the state election board's refusal to extend the cutoff date
column4: saying in its suit that thousands of people would have been deprived of their fundamental right to vote in the Nov. 8 election if Friday's deadline was not extended by at least five days. The judge ordered an extension to next Wednesday in 36 counties
column5: a lawyer for the state Democratic Party said on Twitter.""This ruling will ensure that those communities who have suffered from the devastating flooding brought on by Hurricane Matthew have the grace period that they need in order to exercise their right to vote and make their voices heard in this critical election
column6: party officials said.Twenty-four people have died in North Carolina and thousands have been forced from their homes in the eastern and central parts of the state due to record flooding in Matthew's aftermath.

column1: North Carolina is a battleground state in the presidential election and could play a pivotal role in the race between Democrat Hillary Clinton and Republican Donald Trump.State officials said this week they would not extend the regular deadline to register to vote
column2: but allowances would be made for forms delayed by mail delivery. Those who miss the deadline can still register and vote on the same day during the statewide early voting period from Oct. 20 through Nov. 5.The state has a Republican governor
column3: Pat McCrory
column4: who faces a tough contest for re-election.

column1: The state's Republican Party opposed any extension.""It is clear that North Carolina Democrats
column2: who have been dominated in voter registration by Republicans
column3: want to use a horrific natural disaster to change the rules in the middle of the game
column4: state Republican Chairman Robin Hayes said in a statement.

column1: In Georgia
column2: U.S. District Judge William Moore ordered the voter registration deadline extended until Tuesday in Chatham County
column3: which includes the city of Savannah. The judge said the administrative difficulties of doing so ""pale in comparison to the physical
column4: emotional and financial strain Chatham County residents faced in the aftermath of Hurricane Matthew.""A federal judge on Wednesday gave residents in Florida six extra days to register to vote after that state's Democratic Party sued for more time due to Matthew.South Carolina extended its registration deadline due to Matthew from Oct. 7 to Oct. 11. (Additional reporting by Laila Kearney and Sharon Bernstein; Editing by Chris Reese
column5: Will Dunham and David Gregorio)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-cuba-usa-idUSKBN12E1H3	Obama eases restrictions on Cuba
column2: lifts limits on rum and cigars	"

column1: By Matt Spetalnick and Sarah Marsh
| WASHINGTON/HAVANA

WASHINGTON/HAVANA Americans traveling to Cuba will be allowed to bring home more of the communist-ruled island's coveted cigars and rum under new measures announced by the U.S. government on Friday to further ease trade
column2: travel and financial restrictions that have been in place for decades.Cuba welcomed the steps
column3: part of President Barack Obama's effort to make his historic opening to Cuba ""irreversible"" by the time he leaves office in January
column4: but said they did not go far enough.The latest in a series of new rules since the former Cold War foes began normalizing relations in 2014 will allow Cubans to buy certain U.S. consumer goods online
column5: open the door for Cuban pharmaceutical companies to do business in the United States and let Cubans and Americans do joint medical research.For American travelers
column6: the biggest change is the removal of limits on the amount of rum and cigars they can pack in their luggage
column7: strictly for personal use.""You can now celebrate with Cuban rum and Cuban cigars
column8: U.S. National Security Adviser Susan Rice quipped as she laid out the policy changes in a speech to a Washington think tank.U.S. law still bans general tourism to Cuba
column9: but the administration has used previous regulatory packages to make it easier for Americans to visit the island under 12 officially authorized categories.The latest measures are part of an executive order on Cuba through which Obama seeks to sidestep the Republican-controlled Congress
column10: which has resisted his call to lift Washington's economic embargo after more than 50 years. Republican critics say Obama is making too many concessions to Cuba for too little in return
column11: especially on human rights issues. ""After two years of President Obama's Cuba policy
column12: the Castro regime has made out like bandits

column1: The steps allow Cuban pharmaceutical companies to apply for U.S. regulatory approval
column2: let U.S. firms improve Cuban infrastructure for humanitarian purposes and authorize them to provide safety-related aircraft services in Cuba
column3: where U.S. airlines are beginning regularly scheduled flights.Also under the new rules
column4: after docking in Cuba
column5: some foreign ships carrying certain cargo will be permitted to travel directly to U.S. ports to load or unload freight. Until now
column6: such vessels have been required to wait 180 days
column7: a restriction that Cuban officials say hinders their import export trade.Josefina Vidal
column8: the Cuban Foreign Ministry's chief of U.S. affairs
column9: told a news conference in Havana the measures were ""positive but of a very limited nature"".MAKING THE OPENING ""IRREVERSIBLE""

column1: Today
column2: I approved a Presidential Policy Directive that takes another major step forward in our efforts to normalize relations with Cuba
column3: Obama said in a statement.Less than a month before the Nov. 8 presidential election
column4: Obama said his goal was to ""make our opening to Cuba irreversible.""The latest package
column5: the administration's sixth
column6: is likely to be the ""last significant tranche of changes"" during Obama's tenure
column8: who asked not to be named.Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton backs the policy of rapprochement with Havana. Republican Donald Trump has vowed to roll back Obama's executive actions.

column1: Vidal criticized Obama's directive for making it clear the U.S. aimed to ""promote change in Cuba's economic
column2: political and social system""
column3: failing to respect its sovereignty.In March
column4: Obama made the first visit to Havana by a U.S. president in 88 years. His trip was made possible by his breakthrough agreement with Cuban President Raul Castro in December 2014 to cast aside decades of hostility that began soon after Cuba's 1959 revolution.Since the opening
column5: Obama has repeatedly used his executive powers to relax trade and travel restrictions
column6: while pushing Cuba to accelerate market-style reforms and boost political and economic freedom.""The changes announced to Cuba regulations are
column10: president of the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council. ""Whether they will be relevant depends upon the government of Cuba's willingness to permit United States companies and institutions to engage.""""This new directive consolidates and builds upon the changes we've already made
column13: that ""challenges remain - and very real differences between our governments persist on issues of democracy and human rights.""At the same time
column14: the U.S. embargo against Cuba has remained in place
column15: a major irritant in relations. Only Congress can lift the embargo
column16: and the Republican leadership is not expected to allow such a move anytime soon. (Additional reporting by Susan Heavey
column17: Ayesha Rascoe and Patricia Zengerle in Washington; Marc Frank in Havana; Editing by W Simon

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-idUSKBN12E2IF	Hacked emails raise possibility of Clinton Foundation ethics breach	"
By Jonathan Allen
| SEATTLE
column2: Wash.

column1: SEATTLE
column2: Wash. Hacked emails published by Wikileaks this week appear to show Qatar pledging to donate $1 million to Hillary Clinton's family's charitable foundation
column3: despite her promise to curb new donations by foreign governments while U.S. secretary of state.In an email from 2012
column4: a senior official from the Bill
column5: Hillary & Chelsea Clinton Foundation informs colleagues that a planned donation by Qatar's government to mark Bill Clinton's birthday came up in a meeting he had with the Gulf state's ambassador in Washington.The ambassador said that he asked ""to see WJC 'for five minutes' in NYC
column6: to present $1 million check that Qatar promised for WJC's birthday in 2011
column10: using the former U.S. president's initials. Hillary Clinton
column11: who is the Democratic nominee for the Nov. 8 presidential election
column12: served as secretary of state from 2009 until 2013.The hacked email is among thousands published over the last week by the pro-transparency group Wikileaks from the account of John Podesta
column13: the chairman of Hillary Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign. Clinton's campaign has been embarrassed by this and similar recent hacking attacks on other Democratic Party officials
column14: some of which appear to show Clinton and her aides saying things in private that contradict their public positions. Her spokesmen have not disputed the authenticity of the hacked emails.

column1: The emails released by Wikileaks do not appear to confirm whether Qatar gave the promised $1 million
column2: although the foundation's website lists the State of Qatar as having given at least that amount. There is no date listed for the donation. A spokesman for the foundation declined to confirm the donation.Reuters could not rule out the possibility the $1 million was intended as a birthday present for Clinton personally
column3: not for the foundation. His spokesman did not respond to questions.Hillary Clinton promised the U.S. government that while she served as secretary of state the foundation would not accept new funding from foreign governments without seeking clearance from the State Department's ethics office. The agreement was designed to dispel concerns that U.S. foreign policy could be swayed by donations to the foundation
column4: which is known for its work on reducing the cost of HIV medicine in sub-Saharan Africa. Clinton's Republican rival in the presidential election
column5: Donald Trump
column6: has seized on the foundation for political attacks
column7: calling it a front for corruption. Clinton's campaign dismisses this as a political smear.

column1: The State Department has said it cannot cite any instances of its ethics officials reviewing or approving new donations from foreign governments to the foundation while Clinton served as the country's top diplomat from 2009 until 2013. ""You would need to ask the Foundation whether there were additional matters that it should have submitted for State Department review
column2: the department said in a statement.The ethics agreement allowed foreign governments that already supported foundation projects to continue while Clinton was at the State Department. However
column3: if one of those governments wanted to ""increase materially its commitment
column4: then the foundation was required to ask the department first.

column1: Craig Minassian
column2: a foundation spokesman
column3: declined to confirm if Qatar gave the $1 million described in the 2012 email. Even if it had
column4: he said he questioned whether the money would be considered a ""material increase."" He said Qatar has been donating since 2002
column5: and that some of those donations have been greater than $1 million.Qatar's embassy in Washington did not respond to questions. A spokesman for Clinton
column6: who was campaigning in Seattle on Friday
column7: also did not resond to questions.Last year
column8: Reuters found that at least seven other foreign governments made new donations to the foundation without the State Department being informed
column11: because of ""oversights."" President Barack Obama is campaigning for Clinton to be elected his successor
column12: and the White House has repeatedly declined to discuss the breaches of the agreement Clinton signed with Obama's administration. (Reporting by Jonathan Allen; Editing by Leslie Adler)"
